Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: I sat at my desk, the glow of my monitor illuminating the late hour. My code editor was open, lines of logic sprawled across the screen, but my mind kept drifting. The new feature was almost done, but the code review comments stung: “Performance issues—needs refactoring.” I knew what was expected of me as a developer: clean, efficient code, no shortcuts. But my phone buzzed again with messages from my family group chat. “Don’t forget, tonight is the family dinner. It’s tradition. We all have to be there.” Lately, my parents had been insistent about upholding our customs, especially after my cousin skipped last week. I could almost hear my mother’s voice, disappointed if I missed it. My heart pounded as I stared at the clock, feeling the weight of both worlds. I wanted to be the reliable child, honoring my family’s values, but I also wanted to be the responsible developer, not letting my team down. The two expectations pulled at me, each demanding my full presence, and I sat frozen, torn between the code that needed fixing and the family that needed me.
